title: How to Buy Cheese

steps.headline: Decide what you are making - do you need cheese in part of a recipe, or are you making a tasting plate?

Your recipe will usually tell you which type to look for, but a tasting plate is totally flexible with what you go for from hard cheeses (such as cheddar) through to soft cream type cheeses (such as camembert).
steps.description: As well as brine cheeses such as fetta or bocconcini.

steps.headline: For a tasting plate, you should also buy the accompaniments, such as crackers (salted, plain or seasoned), fruits - usually dried such as apricots, but some fresh fruit such as pear or grape is good with blue vein.
steps.description: Finally things like quince paste or pate or smoked meats, preserved vegetables like sun dried tomatoes etc.

steps.headline: You can cheaply make your own bread crackers by using ordinary sliced bread, roll the slices flat with a rolling pin or leave them plain.
steps.description: Then cut off the crusts and cut into squares or triangles and bake in a cool oven (about 150C) for 10-20 minutes or until crisp and lightly golden.

steps.headline: Go to the grocery store and find where the cheese is.
steps.description: This is usually the dairy refrigerated section with the milk and cream, but occasionally its found with the deli foods such as hams, bacons, fresh pastas etc. Ask if you still cannot find it.

steps.headline: If you have eaten types of cheeses before, go for the types you know.
steps.description: What's your favorite kind of cheese... cheddar, swiss, gouda? Decide which you like best, depending on what you're doing with it.

steps.headline: Select the Cheese.
steps.description: Selecting cheese is basically ruling out cheeses you'd rather not buy. Example: Say, you're choosing between edam, cheddar, and swiss. First, if you know the tastes, find the one you like least, for example edam. Now, depending on what you're doing with the cheese, for example, you're making french onion soup, which would be better, cheddar or swiss? Swiss.

steps.headline: Look for small 50-100g sample portions.
steps.description: They are often little triangle shaped foil parcels that offer a type to try cheaply, rather than buy a big portion.

steps.headline: If you really want to go as cheap as possible for an experience, go to a deli when they are having a cheese tasting day so you can get experience in different tastes.
steps.description: A lot of gourmet delis also allow you to try a sample before you buy, but supermarkets don't offer this service. It is recommended to buy something as a thank you for free tasting days.

steps.headline: The advantage is you can ask the people who know for good types for your need.
steps.description: They may also advise seasonal variations when a particular type is worth going for at this time of year.

steps.headline: Once you've decided your cheese, buy it and enjoy the many wonders of the humble cheese.
